The data show the lower total concentration of heavy metals in studied soil sample than USEPA limits, which reported the 1.5, 200, 50, 200, and 400 mg kg −1 for Cd, Cu, Ni, Pb, and Zn respectively. So, in the present study, it can be mention that there is no risk of heavy metal pollution for E. purpurea growth. The application of mineral fertilizers which have contaminants of trace elements may impose concern regarding the entry and toxic accumulation of these elements in agro ecosystems
37 . So, the chemical composition of 3 types of N fertilizers was analyzed for their content of NO 3 −, HN 4 +, and heavy metals (Table 6).
